_prev_prog_3.Description:
Nation Pizza Products uses a direct ammonia refrigeration system for cooling Process Rooms, Holding Freezers, Coolers, Docks and Blast Freezers.  The refrigeration system uses ammonia refrigerant in a two stage evaporation/condensation cycle.



The ammonia related equipment could be divided into four sections.  

1.    The ?ultra low pressure? equipment contains (2) Blast Freezer Evaporators, (2) Surge Drums, Ultra Low Temp Accumulator (ULTA-1), Transfer Vessel, Oil Pot and (2) Booster Compressors. 

2.    The ?low pressure? equipment contains (4) Freezer Evaporators, Low Temp Accumulator (LTA-1), Transfer Vessel, Oil Pot and (2) Single Stage Compressors.    

3.    The ?intermediate pressure? equipment contains (4) Cooler Evaporators, (5) Corridor Evaporators, (15) Process Room Evaporators, (4) Dock Evaporators, (1) Glycol Chiller, High Temp Accumulator (HTA-1), Intercooler (INT-1), Transfer Vessel, (2) Oil Pots and (3) High Stage Compressors.

4.    The ?high-pressure? equipment includes the (2) Evaporative Condensers, Pilot Receiver, Constant Pressure liquid receiver and associated piping/valves.



Ammonia refrigeration provides cooling by utilizing the heat input required to change a liquid to a vapor (latent heat of evaporation) and then heat output discharged when a gas collapses to form liquid (latent heat of condensation). ?Heat? is quantified by definition and is ?labeled? as calories or Btu (British Thermal Unit).  One Btu, by definition, equals the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of one pound of water, 1 ?F when the water is 70 ?F, and at sea level pressure.  All other compounds reference this definition.  For example, the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of liquid ammonia at 70 ?F and 128.8 psia  = 1.129 Btu/lb (this is also referred to as the ?Specific Heat?). The amount of heat required to vaporize 1 pound of ammonia (at a corresponding pressure to 70 ?F, 128.8 psia) = 508.6 Btu.  Therefore, a system is 500 times more efficient in heat transfer per pound of ammonia utilized if the system incorporates change of state: liquid boiling off forming a vapor.



This ?heat? must be removed from the system or the system would reach a point that no more ?heat? could be absorbed (e.g. the liquid evaporates, and now must be condensed).  This is accomplished by compressing the gas to a pressure such that Air/Water passing over the Condenser coils would accept heat from the gas.  The (vaporized) gas, in rejecting heat, condenses, and thus provides liquid to begin the cycle again.



The ammonia flow direction is based on pressure differences (either by gravity or forced) and by the difference in volume between a gas and a liquid containing the same amount of ammonia.  The active driver of this system is the compressor.



The evaporation/condensation cycle is as follows:

Ultra Low Suction

?    Ammonia gas at low pressure from the Ultra Low Temp Accumulator (ULTA-1) enters the booster compressor suction line and is compressed to higher pressure corresponding intermediate pressure.  The ammonia is co-mingled with lubricating oil in the compressor.



?    The intermediate-pressure gas is directed to the oil separator to remove the majority of oil (employed to lubricate and cool the compressor).



?    The intermediate-pressure vapor passes to the intercooler where it is cooled to the saturated suction temperature of the intermediate suction.



Intermediate Suction

?    Ammonia gas at intermediate pressure from the Intercooler (INT1) and the High Temp Accumulator (HTU-1) enters the high stage compressor suction line and is compressed to higher pressure corresponding to the Saturated Condensing Temperature.  The ammonia is co-mingled with lubricating oil in the compressor.



?    The intermediate-pressure gas is directed to the oil separator to remove the majority of oil (employed to lubricate and cool the compressor).



Low Pressure Suction

?    Ammonia gas at low pressure from the Low Temp Accumulator (LTA-1) enters the singe stage compressor suction line and is compressed to higher pressure corresponding to the Saturated Condensing Temperature.  The ammonia is co-mingled with lubricating oil in the compressor.



?    The intermediate-pressure gas is directed to the oil separator to remove the majority of oil (employed to lubricate and cool the compressor).



High Pressure

?    The high-pressure vapor passes to the evaporative condensers where the latent heat is removed from the gaseous ammonia and the ammonia is condensed into liquid. The fans and water pumps automatically start (sequentially) to maintain the ammonia high-pressure set point.



?    The condensed liquid ammonia is collected in the pilot receiver and then flows into the central constant-pressure receiver.



?    The constant-pressure (CPL) ?sub-cooled? liquid ammonia is directed to all evaporators through a Hand Expansion valve where (CPL) liquid pressure is reduced allowing the  ammonia to remove heat from air passing over the evaporator, vaporizing (boiling) in the process. The Vapor/Liquid is returned to either the Ultra Low Temp Accumulator, Low Temp Accumulator or the High Temp Accumulator depending on which system the evaporator is on. All access liquid is transferred back to the constant pressure receiver utilizing the transfer system on each accumulator.



Secondary Ammonia Cycles

?    High Pressure Liquid (HPL) ammonia is directed from the pilot receiver to the compressors and is injected into the compressor for oil cooling.

III.    Facility Identification

The Nation Pizza Products facility is located at 1144 Bridger Court in McPherson, Kansas.  The facility is a producer of custom and branded frozen sandwiches and dough related products for food marketers and manufacturers, the food service industry, and retailers in the United States. 



The NAICS code for the facility is 31141. Many areas of the plant are refrigerated to preserve ingredients and products.   



The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There is one (1) refrigeration system onsite that is used for refrigerating sandwich ingredients and products. 



The amount of ammonia currently present in the refrigeration system is approximately 17,000 pounds.  The refrigeration system is used to cool process rooms, holding freezers, coolers, docks, and blast freezers.  This refrigeration system uses ammonia refrigerant in a two (2) stage evaporation/condensation cycle.  The "ultra low pressure" equipment contains two (2) blast freezer evaporators with two (2) surge drums, one (1) ultra low temperature accumulator (ULTA-1) with transfer vessel and oil pot, and two (2) booster compressors.  The "low pressure" equipment contains four (4) freezer evaporators, one (1) low temperature accumulator (LTA-1) with transfer vessel and oil pot, and two (2) single stage compressors.  The "intermediate pressure" equipment contains four (4) cooler evaporators, five (5) corridor evaporators, fifteen (15) process room evaporators, four (4) dock evaporators, one (1) glycol chiller, one high temperature accumulator (HTA-1) with transfer vessel and oil pot, one (1) intercooler with oil pot, and three (3) high stage compressors.  The "high pressure" equipment

includes two (2) evaporative condensers, one (1) pilot receiver, one (1) constant pressure liquid receiver and associated piping.



A topographic map identifying the site location is included as Appendix A. 



IV.    Hazard Assessment - Worse Case Scenarios (WCS)

Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the worst-case scenario.  Appendix C consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the worse case release scenario. 



V.    Hazard Assessment - Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS)

Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the alternative release scenario.  Appendix D consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the alternative release scenario. 



VI.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   



This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The first audit of the PSM program occurred on November 19, 2008, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  In addition, a second audit of the PSM program was conducted on October 21, 2011.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.

?    Employee Participation - Nation Pizza Products has updated a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  

?

Process Safety Information - Nation Pizza Products maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. Process safety information for the ammonia process has been compiled and was last reviewed and updated as of October 21, 2011.

?    Process Hazard Review - Nation Pizza Products has updated a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Nation Pizza Products conducted a thorough, initial, PHA study for the refrigeration system during October 2006. A PHA revalidation was conducted on October 18-20, 2011

?    Operating Procedures - Nation Pizza Products has updated a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  Nation Pizza Products developed initial operating procedures for the refrigeration system during October 2006.  Annually, the operating procedures have been reviewed and certified as accurate.

?    Training - Nation Pizza Products has updated a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.

 

?    Management of Change - Nation Pizza Products has updated a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented. 

?    Pre-Startup Review - Nation Pizza Products has updated a s

ite-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.

?    Mechanical Integrity - Nation Pizza Products has updated a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  Nation Pizza Products formalized maintenance procedures for the refrigeration system during October 2006.  In addition, a thorough mechanical integrity inspection of the system occurred on August 19, 2011.

?    Contractor Qualifications - Nation Pizza Products has updated a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers' safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Nation Pizza Products and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency response plan and control over entrance into process areas.

?    Incident Investigation - Nation Pizza Products has updated a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. 

?    Compliance Audit - Nation Pizza Products has updated a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Nation Pizza Products PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.

Compliance audits were conducted on November 19, 2008 and October 21, 2011.   

?    Hot Work Permits - Nation Pizza Products has updated a best management practice for hot work.  Nation Pizza Products updated their hot work permit procedures for the refrigeration system during November 2006. The hot work permits were reviewed on October 21, 2011.

 



VII.    Five-Year Accident History

The Nation Pizza Products facility has not experienced an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



VIII.    Emergency Response Program

Nation Pizza Products has developed an Emergency Action and Response Plan (EARP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. 



Nation Pizza Products annually communicates and trains facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and interact (i.e. onsite inspections) with the McPherson Fire Department. 



Nation Pizza Products has coordinated their EARP with the McPherson County Emergency Management Agency (EMA) and the McPherson Fire Department.  This coordination effort includes providing each aforementioned agency with a copy of our EARP, providing each with a site diagram and hazardous material information, meeting with McPherson Fire Department personnel to discuss the facilities operations/processes, and encouraging periodic on-site inspections and coordination with McPherson Fire Department personnel.



Nation Pizza Products' hazardous materials response team will be responsible for investigating and assisting the McPherson Fire Department (if necessary) with response to accidental releases of ammonia. 



Several employees on staff have received HAZWOPER training through classroom instruction, on-the-job training and d

rills. The current HAZWOPER training includes the incident commander, first responder awareness level, the first responder operations level, and hazardous materials technician training.   



The facility has four (4) windsocks onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.



The current Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E. 



IX.    Emergency Communications

The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.



X.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Chemical safety is an important part of Nation Pizza Products operations. Nation Pizza Products is currently implementing their Process Safety Management Program. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Nation Pizza Products. 



XI.    Management Program

Nation Pizza Products has updated a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Harry Dunker, Plant Manager, is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.
